etymology.description: Pictogram: outline of the chest and upper clothing; compare the upper part of 文. Can split to enclose another component.
etymology.interpretation: Depicts a torso draped in a garment, giving the meaning “clothes.” In later formations it often acts as an enclosing frame or as the clothing component in compounds, embedding other elements in characters like 裹 and 襄.

examples.chinese: 我今天穿新衣(我今天穿新衣)。
examples.english: I am wearing new clothes today.

examples.chinese: 请把外衣挂起来(請把外衣掛起來)。
examples.english: Please hang up the outer garment.

examples.chinese: 她的衣袖被风吹起(她的衣袖被風吹起)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de yīxiù bèi fēng chuī qǐ.
examples.english: Her sleeve was lifted by the wind.
